author: StockTipsTips
body:
Possibly Very Bullish Sectors for the Next 3-12 Months Amid Troubled Times. The examples below are certainly not buy recommendations. Just examples.

Below is a list of what I consider possible bullish sectors/industries in the next 3-12 months. We all know of the supply chain issues, the semiconductor shortages, worker shortages, & inflation issues. As a result I'm considering these sectors/industries as possible bullish options in the next 3-12 Months. Please understand that I know that I did not get all stocks in each category. So if you're favored stock isn't listed, don't get angry, post it in the comments below. And if you feel I missed a sector, please let me know. 

Anyway enjoy the dips now because these are likely to get beefed up as the supply chain & worker shortages unwind

.

**1)** **Inelastic & Fairly inelastic Industries:** (*Meaning people usually pay for the good or service no matter what the price "insensitive to changes in price or income"*) 

* Pharmaceuticals (With highly used patented meds for diseases & illnesses)
* Oil/Gas/Natural Gas (No matter how scarce it gets, people will buy it)
* Energy (Be careful, many producers of electricity are heavily regulated)

**2) Agriculture/Farm Equipment/Fertilizers/Farm Chemicals:** People got to eat ... and have you seen the price of softs futures? This will incentivize farmers to produce more which in turn will require more farm equipment, farm construction, pesticides, herbicides, insecticides, seeds, chemicals etc. It does not help that food is rotting on the docks right now & people are panic buying.

* **Examples:** YTEN, TITN, NTR, SANW, DE, DOLE, ANDE, CLXT, ADM, CLXT, AGRO, AGCO, ADM, LMNR, TWI, ADM, BG, CALM, GRWG, HYFM, FMC, MEOH, 

**3) Semiconductors, Passive Semiconductors, & Electronic Components:** Semiconductors are suffering due to worker shortages & supply chain issues. However demand is seriously backed up. As soon as the supply chain situation gets straightened out expect semiconductors to explode.

* **Examples:** NVDA, INTC, ARCB, AMKR, MU AMD, TXN, VSH, STM, ASYS, WOLF, TSM, QCOM, ON, ASML, NXP, AMAT, AVGO, LRCX, SWKS, MRVL, KLAC, MCHP, QRVO, SSNLF, DIOD

**4) Shipping/Bulk Transportation/Freight/Transportation Services:** Shipping / Bulk Transportation / Freight / Transportation Services / are more in demand now than ever before in US history. In fact these services are in so much demand that they're clogging up the ports. And while ships sitting off the coast are likely loosing money as the supply chain issues worsen, you can bet they'll explode with business for pint up demand as the situation unwinds. 

* **Examples:** ZIM, JBHT, NSC, TNK, TGP, CNI, CMRE, REVG, DAC, SB, HTZZ, GRIN, ODFL, ASC, EDRY, XPO, SBLK, FWRD, BEST, CPLP, MATX, SAIA, INSW, GASS, PATI, PSHG, NETI, PXS, ULH, USDP, TFII, KNOP, KNX, CHRW, GLOP, EDRY, CVLG, PAC, HUBG, EDRY, MRTN, GLNG, NMM, HMLP, BEST, CPLP, DESP, HTLD, PWFL, GOGL, EGLE, SHIP, ZTO, LSTR, WERN, USAK, ESEA, GNK, CICOY, OROVY, PCFBY, CSX, DSX, MMLP,  PANL, KEX, NAT, UNP, WJRYY

**5)** **Chemicals:** Agriculture chemicals, industrial chemicals, construction chemicals, drilling chemicals, textile chemicals, take your pick. The worlds manufacturers do not run without chemicals of some sort. And once supply chain issues are put behind us & workers start to fill these empty job seats, you can bet that increased production will ramp up the demand for industrial chemicals. 

* **EXAMPLES:** HUN, OLN, DOW, LYB, EMN, GLTC, KRO, UNVR, CBT, MEOH, APD, OEC, VHI, ODC, TREC, TROX, IOSP, DD, KOP, ALB, LAC, PPG

**6) Staffing Firms:** There's a massive worker shortage & those positions will need to be filled. You can bet staffing firms are in high demand.

* **EXAMPLES:** DLHC, CCRN, KFY, CBRE, HQI, RHI, WDAY, NSP, HSII, RGP, TBI, KFRC, 

**7) Inferior goods:** Ever notice how demand for some products go up when prices rise? These are generally inferior goods. Ramen Noodles & Mac&Cheese are a few examples. Dollar Stores are filled with inferior goods. 

* DG, DLTR, WMT, ROST, KHC

author: ReThinkingForMyself
body:
It's very interesting to read all of the different perspectives about the chip industry, good stuff. I took a less granular approach. Intel has been an iconic business for my entire adult lifetime and has survived many troubles. I'm not looking for a moon stock, just something that is likely to keep It's value for the next 20 years or so, grow modestly, and keep paying the dividend. Bleeding edge chips are not going to fuel growth forever. Soon we will reach the limits and needs of human perception, and performance/graphics improvements won't have as much value as in the past.

The covid and climate crises appear to predict a contraction in globalization  and a simplification of supply chains, which may benefit Intel in the near future. Its name recognition, market cap, low p/e, importance to American interests, and forward looking attitude all indicate a "buy" to me. I see Texas Instruments  taking advantage of the current situation as well.

author: Capasian
body:
Thank you so much for these two meaningful and insightful posts. For a long time I have been trying to convince my friend to drop Intel stock (mostly based on their shrinking market share, your data nicely adds), but he still believes in the power of inertia. Nevertheless, I had gathered a list of stocks one IMO can use instead, not overperformative, but solid. 

I think that top pick is ASML - instead of betting on a sloppy big player in a growing market, you switch to the main supplier of players in this market. 
Texas Instruments and Analog Devices are good picks if you trust in the electronics segment as a whole, and they provide a wider product mix in terms of electronic components and integrated circuits.
And my favorites also are companies, that produce good measurement instruments. I do solid state physics, and there is funny coincidence - producers of devices I like and use generally show good performance at a stock market. Those are Ametek, Agilent, Keysight, Danaher (Fortive).

Whether you have the opinion on these companies, I would highly appreciate it.

author: BUDDHA_LAUGHING
body: I've read many of the projects first hand at a my job and I can speak to it a bit but it's been a long day and this is a big subject with many aspects.  I will just mention the main one along with some publicly traded companies.  The main buzz word or "thrust" right now is "Digital Twins" for "remote viewing."  Matterport MTTR is mapping and storing the interiors of the world which will be used at some point in the future for the metaverse.  The reverse of this is Snapchat SNAP whose glasses will merge the digital world into your viewing and will be able to record the two together for content posting.  A larger aspect is that 5G is using mmWaves so that mmWave radar can also be part of the 5G towers.  This will allow unmanned drones to fly and film and allow remote viewing in real-time.  MmWave radar chips are now being added to phones (I think mostly from TXN) so that the drones can ping them to navigate indoors unmanned.  These chips also are supposed to work with augmented reality Snapchat or Magic Leap type apps.  Not investment advice.  This is a very boring post for a subject I'm actually excited about.  Sorry, just tired...

author: daydancer
body:
My favorites are blue chip/large cap stocks and I've made some nice returns by doing so. They are not risk-free but way less risk compared to small caps/short squeezes. The strategy is literally buy low, sell high lol. Study the daily chart and find the lows and high of the stocks. Some stocks like to bounce within a range for weeks or even months.

A super great example is TXN. It reached 197 in April and it usually bounces down to its lows (174-180) and bounces back up to 190s. It has repeated this pattern for MONTHS and just yesterday, it hit 186 and today it bounced right back up. AXP has also been fairly predictable, lows (155-161), and highs (171-179). When stocks break out of their range, then I usually stop trading it for awhile to see the new boundaries. At what price you sell is up to you, but my minimum goal is a 2% return but if the stock is looking strong I try to aim for 5% or above. During this choppy market recently, I've also been having major fun with SBUX, V, WM, UPS, AMD, VTI.

How TSMC was build? 
In the late 80s. By experiences of Morris Chang and taiwanese government determination to build tech. Morris Chang passed his PhD at Stanford University in 60s and worked at Texas Instruments for nearly 3 decades before Taiwan government recruited him. 

He holds opinion only real rival to TSMC is Samsung, cause of operating advantages and local talent. American foundries relay on subsidies, which can give short term boost but can not guarantee long term edge. 
Morris Chang find ironic (once) mighty Intel wants enter foundry, when they refused investing into TSMC.

author: moaiii
body:
That doesn't work well with options most of the time due to gamma. You could have a fairly small pullback of the underlying down to a support line or MA which will knock 50% or more off the premium almost instantly. You close, because you couldn't get a fill at 20% down, but then the underlying confirms support and shoots right back up again past your entry point bringing those premiums straight back up with them. You just lost over 50% when the trade was always above support, still trending up, and doing just fine.

Trade on the price action, not the P&L, assume that the cost/margin to enter the trade is your "at risk" amount, and set your position size accordingly.

author: duskick
body: To me, SQ is an earlier version of PayPal.  They are in the process of creating their network.  The benefit they have in the long run in owning the hardware, software, and network, is that they can eliminate Visa and MasterCard from the equation.  If someone uses the Cash app to buy directly from a SQ terminal, the could reduce the charge from 2-3% (of which they get a small cut) to 0-5-1% (of which they get all).  SQ wins, merchant wins, but V and MC lose on such a transaction. PayPal is trying to build a similar network, but doesn’t have as much traction with in person terminals.

author: phohunna
body:
I live in Canada and I recently visited friends in MA where weed was legalized in 2017. Many municipalities still ban the sale.

In Boston, they have like 2 recreational dispensaries for the entire city. We had to bike nearly a half hour from Cambridge, and there were several security guards for the sleepy store. You can't buy with a credit card because the lending banks want nothing to do with it.

In Canada by contrast, its much more like a small fancy liquor store. We have dispensaries every few blocks and zero security guards. You can go in and buy with your credit card.

Companies like TLRY wont take off until there is sufficient distribution and its easy to buy. That wont come until its nationally legalized. Its going to be a long time.

body: if you go to [tradingview.com](https://tradingview.com), go to the chart, click on "indicators" , then search for "MA".  add it to the chart and then you can change the settings for it to show 20 instead of the default which is 9.  The price action of a stock frequently interacts with the moving average, the moving average acts like a rubber band.  The farther the stock moves away from it, the stronger it wants to rebound back.

author: arbiter12
body:
Ma dude... your innocence worries me so i will be harsh.

Do you really think, if the recipe for making money was "[just look for undervalued companies whereby their total share\*value is lower than their Ebitda/cashvalue!](https://corporatefinanceinstitute.com/resources/knowledge/trading-investing/trading-below-cash/)", professional trading houses would spend literal billions in research, algorithm and personnel?

&#x200B;

What you should first learn about this industry, if you want to succeed in it is that if something is easy and/or predictable, then it doesn't work/won't happen. You may get lucky and expect the expected and it happens just as planned, but most often, the big players are contrarian to the market itself, meaning that if you think A is likely and a million people think A is likely, then B is almost guaranteed to happen (unless enough contrarians think B will happen, then probably C)

Traders don't play the game fairly. They just harvest money from betting against the most number of people.

author: RumHam1
body:
Valuing a stock is really difficult and it often boils down to a lot of different assumptions.  Even experts are routinely wrong, so keep that in mind.  What I do for one company normally takes 3-5 hours, and I try to do it quarterly for any company I own.

I will usually start by collecting the company's past, current and future valuation metrics.  Things like price to sales, price to earnings, price to forward earnings, debt ratios, etc.  I compare the 5 year averages to what they currently are.  I also do for their competitors and companies in the same financial space (for example, I'd look at Visa, Mastercard, and other card companies together).  I look at past growth and projected growth to see if I think the valuations are justifiable where they currently are.

I look through the financial statements and try to spot trends in cash flow, debt, margin, and many other things to see how the company is performing yoy and qoq.

I look at how the company is engaging with the industry and where they are projecting their growth to come from.  Are the expanding market share, is the sector growing, etc.  I need the company to justify why it can achieve or surpass their growth estimates.

I listen to their most recent conference calls and look though any articles I can find, but I heavily discount opinion pieces.  I actively seek out reasons why this company will fail.

After all of this, I try to put together a balanced view of where the company is valued now vs historically and also vs their competition.  It requires a lot of projection and assumptions and I only do it for companies that I can understand their business model.  You have to go into the process without bias, and to be honest the majority of companies that I do this for aren't buys at the time.

author: dontgetmadgetdata
body:
I like it. The price is pretty elevated off it’s 50 day MA due to a nice post earnings drift. It has kissed its 50 day 5 times this year. To increase your probability of profit, I might wait until it consolidates/retraces to around this area and open up the position at that time. Possibly move the strike closer to that stock price to further increase the leverage. 

For example, If it retraces to closer to $300 level and open contracts with $280-$300 strike. You would still need around $350 to break even if the cost is halved but you would have substantially more leverage per dollar.
